English teacher | employer = | organization = | known_for = | notable_works = ''Notes from the Other China'' | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | party = | movement = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = Foster Parfitt | relatives = | awards = | signature = | website = }} '''Troy Parfitt''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]]{{cite news |title= PARFITT, FOSTER |publisher= ''Telegraph-Journal'' |quote= Foster is survived by one son Troy Parfitt ... |date= August 4, 2009 |url= http://telegraphjournal.canadaeast.com/classifieds/obituaries/listing.php?id=230811&t=0&c=8&pub=2&period= |accessdate= 2011-04-27 }}{{cite news |author= Craig Ferguson |title= Notes From The Other China – book launch |publisher= ''craig ferguson images (newsletter)'' |year= 2006 |url= http://www.craigfergusonimages.com/2007/12/notes-from-the-other-china-book-launch/ |accessdate= 2011-04-27 }} [[author]] and traveler who focuses on critical travel commentary and cultural exposes. He grew up in [[New Brunswick, Canada]] but has lived in [[Taipei, Taiwan|Taiwan]] and [[Korea]] and has taught [[English language|English]] as a second language in East Asia for twelve years. He wrote two books, called ''Notes From The Other China'' and ''Why China Will Never Rule the World''. As well as this he also taught History for a year in Scotland. ==Reviews== Reviewer Bradley Winterton in the ''Taipei Times'', reviewing his first book, described Parfitt as a "bad traveler, an insensitive loud-mouth ranting on about the absurdities of life ''abroad''".{{cite news |author= Bradley Winterton (book reviewer) Troy Parfitt (author) |title= 'Notes From the Other China' stirs emotions |publisher= ''Taipei Times'' |quote= ''Notes from the Other China'' is the memoir of a Canadian, Troy Parfitt, ... |date= Jan 20, 2008 |url= http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2008/01/20/2003398111 |accessdate= 2011-04-27 }} Reviewer John Burroughs described it as "travel commentary and cultural analysis."{{cite news |author= John Burroughs |title= Reviewer's Bookwatch |publisher= ''Midwest Book Review'' |quote= Volume 8, Number 2 -- Troy combines memoir with travel commentary and cultural analysis w... |date= February 2008 |url= http://www.midwestbookreview.com/rbw/feb_08.htm |accessdate= 2011-04-27 }} Reviewer Alan Caruba in the ''Canada Free Press'' described Parfitt as his "own man" with an "eye for detail and a talent for describing his journey in ways that do not ignore some obvious and ugly truths about the real China."{{cite news |author= Alan Caruba (reviewer) |title= China is NOT the Future (op-ed piece) |publisher= ''Canada Free Press'' |quote= Parfitt is his own man... |date= March 21, 2011 |url= http://www.canadafreepress.com/index.php/article/34674 |accessdate= 2011-04-27 }} Reviewer Terence P. Ward of ''AllBooks Review'' wrote that Parfitt is "fluent in Mandarin" and "brings a lot of information to the table" to back up his claims about China being filthy, overcrowded, with unimaginable poverty, and "pollution so thick that it obscures the sun".{{cite news |author= Terence P Ward |title= (book title:) Why China Will Never Rule the World |publisher= ''AllBooks Review'' |date= April 2011 |url= http://www.allbooksreviewint.com/ReviewShowcase.html |accessdate= 2011-04-28 }} According to Ward, Parfitt argues that "China is romanticized, and cannot possibly ever rule the world because its population is willfully ignorant, poorly educated, and clueless about the world beyond that nation's borders." ''Vancouver Sun'' reviewer Jonathan Manthorpe agreed with Parfitt's conclusion that "China is unlikely to be an influential [[superpower]] because its current regime has no vision, its economy has developed no capacity for innovation, and there is no sense of optimism" as well as Parfitt's assessment that "China is a gloomy, bitter, [[xenophobic]] and ill-favoured place."{{cite news |author= Jonathan Manthorpe (reviewer) |title= Thesis that China lacks superpower qualities is sound |publisher= ''Vancouver Sun'' |date= May 2, 2011 |url= https://vancouversun.com/Thesis+that+China+lacks+superpower+qualities+sound/4708471/story.html |accessdate= 2011-05-04 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Parfitt, Troy}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Writers from New Brunswick]] [[Category:Canadian travel writers]] [[Category:Cultural critics]] [[Category:Writers about China]] [[Category:1972 births]]

An '''uncertain plural''' occurs when a writer does not know in advance whether a word should be written in the [[Grammatical number|singular]] or [[plural]]. For [[English language|English]] nouns, this may be demonstrated by enclosing the trailing ''s'' in parentheses, such as "book(s)".
In the case of articles, "they" or "their" may be used to include a single individual, when uncertain.

{{Redirect-distinguish|Balis|Barbalissos}} {{For|the surname|Bališ}} '''Usog''' or '''balis''' is a topic in psycho-medicine in [[Filipino Psychology]] (but considered just as a [[Philippines|Filipino]] superstition in Western Psychology) where an affliction or psychological disorder is attributed to a greeting by a stranger, or an [[evil eye]] [[Curse|hex]]. It usually affects an unsuspecting child, usually an infant or toddler, who has been greeted by a visitor or a stranger.<ref>[http://www.stuartxchange.com/PweUsog.html PWE-USOG / PWE-BUYAG: Miscellaneous Therapies in Philippine Alternative Medicine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In some limited areas, it is said that the condition is also caused by the stranger having an evil eye or ''masamang mata'' in [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]], lurking around. This may have been influenced by the advent of the Spaniards who long believed in the ''[[mal de ojo]]'' superstition.
Once affected, the child begins to develop [[fever]], and sometimes [[convulsion]]s. Supposedly, the child can be cured by placing its clothing in hot water and boiling it. In most other places, to counter the effects of the "usog" the stranger or newcomer is asked to put some of his or her [[saliva]] on the baby's abdomen, shoulder or forehead before leaving the house. The newcomer then leaves while saying: "''Pwera usog... pwera usog...''" The saliva is placed on the finger first, before the finger is rubbed on the baby's abdomen or forehead. The stranger is never to lick the child.<ref>http://www.viloria.com/secondthoughts/archives/00000176.html</ref> The practice is that the stranger or visitor is asked to touch his or her finger with saliva to the child's body, arm or foot (''"lawayan"'') to prevent the child from getting overpowered (''"upang hindi mausog"'').
==Possible scientific explanation==
One theory (Kristina Palacio)<ref>Fadul, J. Public Forum on Witchcraft and Illnesses. Rizal Technological and Polytechnic Institute, Morong, Rizal. July 24, 1988.</ref><ref name="100% PINOY">100% PINOY (Kapuso Network's cultural program on GMA7 featuring Filipino Culture and Ingenuity to strengthen the Filipino identity.) Aired internationally through GMA Pinoy TV. "Bata, bata, paano ka ginawa?" episode aired August 28, 2008. Pinoy culture, beliefs and practices about "paglilihi, pagbubuntis, panganganak at pag-aalaga sa bata".</ref> explains ''usog'' in terms of child distress that leads to greater susceptibility to illness and diseases. There are observations that a stranger (or a newcomer or even a visiting relative) especially someone with a strong personality (physically big, boisterous, has strong smell, domineering, etc.) may easily distress a child. Thus, the child is said to be "overpowered" or ''nauusog'' and thus may feel afraid, develop fever, get sick, etc.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cohen S, Janicki-Deverts D, Miller GE | title = Psychological stress and disease. | journal = JAMA | volume = 298 | issue = 14 | pages = 1685–7 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17925521 | url = http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/extract/298/14/1685 | doi = 10.1001/jama.298.14.1685}} "Stress Contributes To Range Of Chronic Diseases, Review Shows" ScienceDaily.com (Oct. 10, 2007) [https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/10/071009164122.htm]</ref>
In ''usog'', the child's distress is the consequence of the child's failure to adapt to change. It is, in [[medical]] terms, the consequence of the disruption of homeostasis through physical or psychological stimuli brought about by the stranger.<ref name="Revisiting">{{cite book | last = Tan | first = Michael | authorlink = Michael Tan | title = Revisiting Usog, Pasma, Kulam | publisher = University of the Philippines Press | year = 2008 | location = Quezon City | pages = 178 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-971-542-570-4}}</ref> Technically, the condition results from the child-environment interaction that leads the child to perceive a painful discrepancy, real or imagined, between the demands of a situation on the one hand and their social, biological, or psychological resources on the other. The stressful stimuli to the child may be mental (stranger is perceived as a threat, malevolent or demanding), physiological (loud and/or high-pitched voice of the stranger that is hurting to the child's eardrum; strong smell of the stranger that irritates the child's nasal nerves), or physical (stranger has heavy hands or is taking up too much space).
The stranger's act of gently placing his finger with his saliva to the child's arm, foot, or any particular part of the child's body, could make him more familiar to the child, and thus, reduce if not remove the stress. As the stranger keeps gently saying, "Pwera usog... pwera usog...," the child is made to feel and assured that he means no harm. The ''usog'' is said to be counteracted because the child is prevented from succumbing to an illness since the child is no longer in distress. Children or even adults who are shy or have weak personalities are more susceptible to ''usog'' in accordance with observations and theory. Some have observed that at times even praising a shy child by a visiting relative caused an ''usog''.<ref name="100% PINOY"/><ref>Youtube [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JakqnTEuUsE Usog]</ref>
The saliva from the stranger, granted that he or she is healthy and consistent with his or her [[oral hygiene]], is relatively clean<ref>http://neurophilosophy.wordpress.com/2006/11/14/lick-your-wounds/ Neurophilosophy: Lick your wounds</ref> and contains enough [[antimicrobial]] compounds such as [[lactoferrin]], [[lactoperoxidase]], and secretory [[immunoglobulin A]] which can help clear [[pathogens]] from the child and benefit the child against infection.<ref>[http://www.discover.com/issues/oct-05/departments/the-biology-of-saliva/ Discover Magazine, "The Biology of ...Saliva" October 2005]</ref> Furthermore, human saliva has [[opiorphin]], a newly researched pain-killing substance. Initial research with mice shows the compound has a painkilling effect of up to six times that of morphine. It works by stopping the normal breakdown of natural pain-killing opioids in the spine, called [[enkephalins]]. Opiorphin in human saliva is a relatively simple molecule, and the child's immune system may trigger a [[biochemical cascade]] ([[complement system]]) to produce other stress-reducing compounds.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wisner |first=Anne |author2=Evelyne Dufour |author3=Michaël Messaoudi |author4=Amine Nejdi |author5=Audrey Marcel |author6=Marie-Noelle Ungeheuer |author7=Catherine Rougeot |title=Human Opiorphin, a natural antinociceptive modulator of opioid-dependent pathways |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] |volume=103 |pages=17979–17984 |date=November 13, 2006 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0605865103 |pmid=17101991 |issue=47 |pmc=1693858}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn10514|title=Natural-born painkiller found in human saliva|author=Andy Coghlan|publisher=[[New Scientist]]|date=November 13, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/6142842.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|title=Natural chemical 'beats morphine'|date=November 14, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://sciencenow.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/2006/1113/3|title=Prolonging Painkillers|author=Mary Beckman|publisher=[[Science (journal)|ScienceNOW]]|date=November 13, 2006}}</ref>
Usog can also, though less commonly, affect adults, and it may induce vomiting and stomach ache rather than fever. Supposedly, it can be prevented by stopping a stranger or visitor from greeting the person.
Unlike "[[lihi]]", however, usog is not yet medically accepted. More than the superstitious folks, researchers dealing with Filipino Psychology say they have observed this phenomenon with regularity and suggest that this be added to the Psychiatric Disorders Handbook [[DSM-V]].<ref name ="100% PINOY" />
